situations.text: A patient has been told that he has 6 months to live and there are no feasible treatments available. He insists, however, on a course of treatment that the doctor knows is unlikely to have any positive impacts on the patient’s longevity. How important to take into account are the following considerations for the doctor when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The right of the patient to be autonomously involved in his own treatment
questions.explanation: Patients with adequate mental capacity have the right to be involved in decisions regarding their treatment – this is a fundamental pillar of medical ethics

questions.text: That the medical team have more experience and expertise when it comes to choosing treatments
questions.explanation: While this may be true, the patient still has a role in deciding his treatment and should be listened to by the treating team

questions.text: Being positive and optimistic
questions.explanation: While it is important to maintain a positive outlook for the patient, this should not cloud the doctor’s understanding of the risks and limitations associated with ‘futile’ treatment

questions.text: That the patient might not have a clear understanding of the treatment and its pros and cons
questions.explanation: It is essential that the patient is adequately informed about a treatment before they commit to that course of action

questions.text: That the doctor does not believe that the pros of this treatment outweigh the cons
questions.explanation: While the doctor’s professional opinion should be valued, the patient’s views, thoughts and desires should also be considered

situations.text: A medical student, Petunia, has noticed her friend Joshua’s abrupt behaviour with patients. He doesn’t always ask for consent, often speaks in a condescending tone and can be quite rough as well. Most patients, however, don’t say anything about it. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Petunia when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The effect Joshua might be having on the reputation of the healthcare profession in the eyes of patients
questions.explanation: While it is important for medical students to uphold the reputation of the healthcare profession, there are other more pressing concerns including the impacts on patient welfare and trust

questions.text: Patients may not be comfortable sharing information with Joshua or other doctors
questions.explanation: This shows that Joshua’s actions are negatively impacting doctor-patient relationships and patient care

questions.text: That Joshua does not have malicious intents and often does so without realising
questions.explanation: Irrespective of the reason behind Joshua’s actions, patient care may be compromised, and action should be taken. The fact that Joshua does so without realising should, however, be an incentive to alert him to the effect he is having on patients

questions.text: That Joshua’s behaviour may make patients more reluctant to allow medical students to interview/exam them
questions.explanation: While this is definitely true, there are other more pressing concerns including the impacts on patient welfare and trust

questions.text: How Joshua will feel if Petunia raises the issue with the supervisor
questions.explanation: Patient welfare is the utmost priority here and regardless of how Joshua will react or feel, the issue must be dealt with

situations.text: Cindy is a junior doctor and is known for being forgetful; however, she is working on this. The previous day, a senior doctor had asked Cindy and Kathy, another medical student, to conduct a test on a patient. It was decided that Cindy would carry out the test but has forgotten to do so. The next day, the doctor asks for the results of the test. Kathy says nothing. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Cindy when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: Displaying honesty to the doctor
questions.explanation: Honesty and integrity are essential amongst healthcare professionals and admitting mistakes is pivotal

questions.text: That the doctor may get frustrated if he realises that she made another mistake
questions.explanation: To withhold information on this basis would be unprofessional – Cindy should own up to her mistake

questions.text: That she can blame Kathy for the issue
questions.explanation: Blaming Kathy, when it was agreed that Cindy would conduct the test, would be deceptive and highly unethical

questions.text: Taking action to reduce the likelihood of this happening again
questions.explanation: Everyone makes mistakes, the key is to reflect and learn from one’s errors in a professional manner to reduce the risk of them happening again

questions.text: That the doctor didn’t remind Cindy or Kathy to conduct the test
questions.explanation: It is not the doctor’s obligation to remind Cindy to conduct the test – she should have made note of this requirement herself

situations.text: Raman makes clinical skills notes which he sends to the medical cohort to help others in their preparation. Upon reviewing Raman’s notes, Matthew sees a picture of a patient from a consultation, this patient has not been deidentified and his name is visible. How important are the following considerations for Matthew when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That another student will likely report this
questions.explanation: It is incorrect to assume that another student would take action – Matthew should take a more proactive approach

questions.text: That Raman’s notes help out the whole cohort
questions.explanation: While this may be the case, patient information has been made available and, hence, action needs to be taken

questions.text: That the faculty should be alerted to this immediately
questions.explanation: While alerting the faculty to this will help resolve the situation, Raman should be first notified

questions.text: That Raman should be alerted to this immediately
questions.explanation: Raman may have unknowingly included this photo in his notes and should be alerted urgently so he can rectify this

questions.text: That the patient is very easy-going and probably wouldn’t mind
questions.explanation: Patient confidentiality must be upheld and, regardless of the patient’s nature, their private information should not be revealed to the medical cohort

situations.text: Michael has noticed that his friend, Robert, has changed recently. He has become withdrawn, antisocial and rude; he doesn’t even want to attend social events. He is studying medicine along with Michael and Michael believes that Robert might be having a hard time at home. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Michael when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That he should be there for Robert, if he needs someone to talk to
questions.explanation: As a friend, Michael should seek to keep an open channel of communication with Robert and provide support

questions.text: Robert will return to his normal self soon so he should not intervene
questions.explanation: While this may occur, Michael shouldn’t rely on this assumption. Potentially, Robert’s frame of mind could get worse instead

questions.text: That Robert may not want to talk
questions.explanation: While this should shape Michael’s approach to the situation, Michael should seek to open up dialogue regardless – especially being a close friend and given that Robert’s behaviour may be affecting others

questions.text: That Robert’s grades are being affected and it may impact his ability to be a doctor in the future
questions.explanation: Robert’s frame of mind may have reverberating impacts on his life and his career and, hence, Michael should seek to help him out in this scenario

questions.text: That there are support services for Robert to utilise and he may not be aware of these
questions.explanation: Michael should definitely outline the support services available for Robert to utilise to help him through this difficult time

situations.text: A medical student, Gloria, is working on a hospital ward. A patient, Bill, with severe back pain, is ready to be discharged. Gloria observes Bill taking a walking stick, from the hospital supplies without consulting anyone. Gloria knows that staff must provide permission for any of the supplies to be taken by a patient. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Gloria when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That Bill should not leave with the walking stick that has not been authorised
questions.explanation: It is against hospital policy to do so and this walking stick may be not suited for Bill or designated for someone else

questions.text: That none of the other stuff appears to have noticed
questions.explanation: Regardless of whether others have seen this action, it is essential for Gloria to intervene in this situation

questions.text: That Bill needs the stick to help him walk
questions.explanation: While this may be the case, it still needs to be properly authorised by hospital staff regardless

questions.text: That there are plenty of walking sticks in the supplies
questions.explanation: This is completely irrelevant. It is hospital policy to authorise the transferral of supplies and this must be done regardless

questions.text: That hospital staff should be notified of this
questions.explanation: It is essential that hospital policy is upheld and Gloria notifies the members of staff

situations.text: Dr Garthwaite has referred one of her patients to see a surgeon for an operation. While she knows that this surgeon is excellent at what he does, the patient appears uncomfortable. He states that he hasn’t heard good things about surgeon. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Dr Garthwaite when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That she is confident in the surgeon’s abilities
questions.explanation: The surgeon’s abilities will directly affect the outcome of the patient’s operation and if she is confident in him, she should tell this to the patient

questions.text: That there is no evidence of malpractice by the surgeon
questions.explanation: This is very important as the patient’s concerns are founded on rumours only and her opinion on this should be based on facts

questions.text: That she should explore the patient’s concerns further
questions.explanation: It is very appropriate to listen to the concerns of the patient and hear them out – to help reassure the patient

questions.text: Ask the patient if she should check whether another surgeon is free
questions.explanation: While this recognises the patient’s concerns, the doctor should seek to flesh out these concerns further and see whether there is a basis to them

questions.text: That the surgeon is a friend of Dr Garthwaite
questions.explanation: Personal acquaintances should not dictate Dr Garthwaite’s approach to the scenario – the priority is the patient’s outcome

situations.text: Kathryn is a GP, and she is undertaking a consultation with Mrs Green, a 42 year-old woman. Mrs Green has had 2 children in the past 3 years and she is in the early stages of her 3rd. Kathryn has previously told Mrs Green that, after 35, the risk of genetic abnormalities of the child and potentially life-threatening birth complications increases exponentially. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Kathryn when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That if she does not inform Mrs Green again about these risks, Mrs Green may become pregnant again and risk birth complications/genetic abnormalities
questions.explanation: Without imparting judgement, it is very important for the doctor to explain the risks and potential health complications to the patient

questions.text: That the information about these risks is provided respectfully
questions.explanation: Advice should always be delivered in a respectful and caring way so as not to upset Mrs the patient

questions.text: That Mrs Green is given all the information she needs to make informed decisions in the future
questions.explanation: Kathryn cannot enforce any behaviour/courses of action to be carried out by the patient, she can only provide advice and help Mrs Green make a decision

questions.text: That Mrs Green should be told not to have another child due to the risks associated
questions.explanation: Kathryn cannot enforce any behaviour/courses of action to be carried out by the patient, she can only provide advice and help Mrs Green make a decision

questions.text: That Mrs Green should be told to abort her child due to the risks associated
questions.explanation: Kathryn cannot enforce any behaviour/courses of action to be carried out by the patient, she can only provide advice and help Mrs Green make a decision

situations.text: During a GP placement, Julia observes Lawrence, another medical student, taking a video on his mobile phone. While the university/clinic policy allows this for educational purposes, anything related to patient information cannot be discussed. Patient information and the patient’s name has been discussed during the consult. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Julia when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That importance of following policy
questions.explanation: Policy is in place to protect all those involved and should always be adhered to

questions.text: That she does not know whether Lawrence has gotten permission to record
questions.explanation: Lawrence may or may not have been given permission to record the consult – either way, Julia shouldn't make an assumption until she has found out the facts

questions.text: Maintaining the confidentiality of patient information
questions.explanation: All patients have the fundamental right to privacy and all medical practitioners must strive to maintain this confidentiality – recording without permission may be a breach of this

questions.text: That the patient’s name and information has been mentioned
questions.explanation: Recording this is strictly against the policy and thus this is an essential consideration

questions.text: Recording the interaction may help Lawrence’s learning
questions.explanation: Patient welfare and privacy must come before this notion; hence, relatively, the benefit to Lawrence’s learning has no bearing whatsoever

situations.text: Jim and Dylan are currently junior doctors working together ad have been good friends since medical school. Recently, Jim has noticed Dylan’s behaviour change. He appears frustrated and confused and has been making more errors recently. Dylan tells Jim that he has been having issues with his relationship and is striggling at the moment. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Jim when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That other staff may have more of a workload due to Dylan’s behaviour and errors
questions.explanation: While the workload of staff is an important consideration, it is more important to consider the direct effects on Chris' own patients

questions.text: That Dylan has been making mistakes when interacting with patients
questions.explanation: While mistakes are part of the process, they should be learned from. Repeated mistakes may be putting patient welfare at risk

questions.text: That Dylan has been abrupt with patients
questions.explanation: Being irritable or abrupt with patients is unacceptable, this can impact patient trust and is not professional

questions.text: That Dylan has been rude with other staff
questions.explanation: This is unprofessional, may erode working relationships in the hospital and may ultimately jeopardise patient care

questions.text: That Dylan might need his space to deal with the situation and doesn’t want to talk about it
questions.explanation: While this may be true, the welfare and impacts of his behaviour on patient and staff are the primary concern here and his behaviour should be addressed regardless

situations.text: Christian is working as a junior doctor at a GP clinic. He enters the waiting room to collect his next patient and, to his surprise, his uncle has booked in for an appointment. After the consultation, Christian’s uncle asks if he can be bulk billed. Christian is aware that, according to clinic policy, doctors can only bulk bill patients if they are struggling financially. Christian is aware that his uncle is quite affluent. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Christian in this situation?

questions.text: Comply with his uncle’s request
questions.explanation: Christian must comply with clinical policy and, thus, cannot bulk bill his patient

questions.text: Politely inform his uncle that he will be unable to comply with his request due to clinical policy
questions.explanation: It is advisable for Christian to politely inform his uncle about clinical policy, to ensure that he doesn’t break the rules or upset his uncle

questions.text: Tell his uncle that he will be unable to see him as a patient in the future due to a conflict of interest
questions.explanation: While this may help avoid a similar situation in the future, there is nothing in the scenario to suggest that it is against clinical policy to see family members so this response may be an overreaction

questions.text: Ask a senior doctor at the clinic whether he can bulkbill his uncle
questions.explanation: While it is good that Christian is seeking confirmation from a senior doctor, it not appropriate to seek to defy clinical policy in any way

questions.text: Pay for the treatment himself
questions.explanation: While this may help placate his uncle, this response is unnecessary and is not appropriate – as for other patients this cannot be done

situations.text: A medical student, Kyra, is on a clinical placement with a doctor. This doctor seems to interact well with patients and occasionally makes a few light-hearted jokes with them. During a consultation with a patient, Mohammed, the doctor makes what seems to be a racist joke. The patient does not seem to be offended by it. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Kyra in this situation?

questions.text: Calmly interrupt the conversation and tell the doctor that the comments are inappropriate
questions.explanation: This concern should be discussed in private, not in front of the patient (who, didn’t even appear offended by the comment)

questions.text: Politely and privately raise the concern with the doctor afterwards
questions.explanation: If Kyra perceived the comment to be offensive, she has the right to raise it with him in a non-confrontational manner

questions.text: Raise the matter with her supervisor
questions.explanation: It is not appropriate to escalate the issue in such a manner and, if she felt uncomfortable, she should raise it with the supervisor

questions.text: Apologise to the patient for the comment afterwards
questions.explanation: While there are no immediately negative consequences this would bring about, it should be the responsibility of the individual who made the comment to apologise and, additionally, the patient didn’t seem to be offended by the comment

questions.text: Laugh at the joke
questions.explanation: It is highly inappropriate to laugh at the joke if the comment may be racist as this will only reinforce such behaviour in the mind of the doctor and may upset Mohammed

situations.text: Ava and Jett are medical students, and they have an upcoming oral presentation this week. They have chosen the same topics and have agreed to practice their presentations in front of each other. As Ava reads out her second body paragraph, Jett feels a sense of familiarity. He then realises that the exact same paragraph was in an online article that he read while doing research. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Jett in this situation?

questions.text: Ask Ava if she copied the paragraph from the article
questions.explanation: Jett should first consult Ava and obtain further information before deciding how to proceed

questions.text: Don’t say anything as he may be mistaken
questions.explanation: If there is even a chance that plagiarism has occurred, Jett should investigate the matter further

questions.text: Ask Ava if she needs help with her presentation
questions.explanation: While Ava may have had some trouble with her assignment and resorted to plagiarism as a result, the primary concern is whether plagiarism has actually occurred

questions.text: Alert the tutor to the possibility that Ava has plagiarised her presentation
questions.explanation: While it is important to report plagiarism, Jett needs more information before he can proceed further – he doesn’t know for certain whether plagiarism has occurred and whether this is a draft or her actual presentation. As such, he should check with Ava

questions.text: Ask Ava to send through her script so he can use a plagiarism checker
questions.explanation: While this may help Jett to definitively occur whether plagiarism has occurred, Ava has no obligation to send her script to him – as she may be concerned that Jett could use parts of her speech in his presentation

situations.text: Caleb is a medical student, and he has been asked to vaccinate a patient. The patient is evidently scared of needles and appears to be visibly shaking. When Caleb introduces himself as a medical student, the patient appears even more shocked and worried. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Caleb in this situation? Assume all responses would be said sensitively and politely.

questions.text: I’ve done this many times before, don’t worry
questions.explanation: While this may be appropriate in addressing the patient’s concerns, it isn’t directly addressing their concerns and consent should be obtained first

questions.text: Would you prefer if I ask the doctor to take your blood?
questions.explanation: Caleb has been asked to vaccinate the patient and it isn’t ideal to simply assume that the patient would be uncomfortable with him doing so – the patient’s concerns should be explored in more detail

questions.text: You seem a bit nervous. Are you ok?
questions.explanation: This is very appropriate as it will provide patient with an opportunity to express their concerns, so that they can then be resolved

questions.text: As medical students, we are just as qualified as other doctors
questions.explanation: This response does not properly address the patient’s concerns and isn’t actually true – medical students are doctors in training

questions.text: Ok I’ll quickly give this injection and it’ll be done in no time
questions.explanation: While telling the patient that it will be over quickly may help relax the patient, Caleb shouldn’t rush into the treatment – he should get the patient’s thoughts first

situations.text: Emma is a junior doctor and has to stitch up a relatively large abrasion on a patient’s leg. Emma hasn’t sewn up an abrasion that big before and is quite nervous about doing so. After conducting the first stitch, she believes that it is not in the right area (as the patient moved slightly) and that she should redo it. Redoing the stitch is perfectly safe but may cause the patient to experience a bit more pain. The patient appears anxious too. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Emma in this situation?

questions.text: Explain to the patient what has happened and reassure him that there is no harm done
questions.explanation: Given the nervousness displayed by the patient and the importance of open communication, it is very appropriate for Emma to explain and reassure him

questions.text: Tell the patient to calm down and that she has to redo the stitch because he moved
questions.explanation: Telling the patient to calm down is counterproductive as he is already anxious and medical professionals should never impart blame or judgement on their patients

questions.text: Politely ask the patient to try to remain still if possible
questions.explanation: Without imparting blame or judgement, it is highly appropriate for Emma to communicate politely what is required of the patient to avoid any further setbacks

questions.text: Apologise to the patient for the setback
questions.explanation: If a mistake has been made or a procedure has been delayed in any way, it is definitely appropriate for the doctor to apologise for the inconvenience

questions.text: Report the error as the hospital requires all errors, even minor errors, to be reported
questions.explanation: It is important for Emma to acknowledge, not hide behind, the error and follow hospital policy

situations.text: Blake and Jackson are medical students in the same cohort – and good friends. Blake has recently sat the end of semester test. Jackson, who was sick for much of the semester, has been granted a deferment on the test. Jackson approached Blake and asks if he can help him out with his test preparation. He specifically asks Blake to tell him what questions popped up on the test. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Blake in this situation?

questions.text: Help Jackson with his preparation and provide him access to his notes – but not tell him the questions on the test
questions.explanation: This is very appropriate as Blake will be able to help Jackson with his preparation without engaging in academic misconduct

questions.text: Encourage Jackson to ask the academic tutor for help in his preparation
questions.explanation: Jackson will be able to get the correct advice from the tutor, and this will ensure that he doesn’t receive any unfair advantage

questions.text: Agree to Jackson’s request as he has been sick for much of the semester
questions.explanation: It is entirely inappropriate for Blake to divulge the contents of the test – regardless of Jackson’s situation

questions.text: Not help out Jackson or agree to his request
questions.explanation: While Blake cannot agree to Jackson’s request, he can still help Jackson out with his preparation

questions.text: Ask Jackson to pass on his request to another student as he doesn’t want to get in trouble
questions.explanation: Blake should not encourage Jackson to request this from another student – he must remind him that this is not honourable academic conduct

situations.text: Chloe and Clara are conducting an upper limb examination on a patient, Janice. Chloe examines Janice’s shoulder and concludes that her shoulder is not injured. Clara performs the examination afterwards and believes that Janice’s shoulder is damaged and inflamed. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Clara in this situation?

questions.text: With Janice’s consent, explain to Chloe where she believes the damage is
questions.explanation: Janice is aware that the Chloe and Clara are medical students, and if she is thus ok with them re-examining, it could be a valuable learning experience for both students

questions.text: Ask the supervising doctor to check
questions.explanation: The supervisor can confirm which student is correct and highlight the correct technique to conduct the examination

questions.text: Tell Chloe that she is incorrect
questions.explanation: This is very inappropriate thing to do without knowing who is correct. Not only might this be misleading, but it may hurt Chloe’s self-esteem and embarrass her in front of the patient

questions.text: Apologise to the patient and ask if they can both re-examine
questions.explanation: It is important to seek permission from the patient and, subsequently, the students can consult with each other and re-examine the shoulder as necessary

questions.text: Take Chloe’s word for it as she is known to be very intelligent
questions.explanation: Regardless of reputations and intelligence, Clara should pursue this further and seek to clarify the examination process – with Chloe and even the supervisor perhaps

situations.text: Devon, a medical student, has been under a lot of stress recently. His mother, who is a single parent, has recently become sick and he must look after his younger siblings. At a clinical placement, it is evident that Devon is tired and withdrawn and his supervisor picks up on this. He complains about Devon’s lack of enthusiasm and states that he will have to mark him down and provide negative feedback if this continues. Leah, another student, is in the room when this happens and is aware of Devon’s situation. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Leah in this situation?

questions.text: Speak up on Devon’s behalf and mention that he has been having issues at home
questions.explanation: Whilst there are reasons for his behaviour, Devon’s actions are inappropriate and fairly picked up on by the supervisor. Additionally, Leah should respect Devon’s privacy as he may not wish to divulge this to this supervisor

questions.text: Not interfere at all
questions.explanation: Remaining silent is appropriate as Devon’s actions are inappropriate and fairly picked up on by the supervisor and Leah should respect Devon’s privacy. However, she should raise the matter in private with Devon

questions.text: Tell the supervisor to be more empathetic of Devon
questions.explanation: Leah is not in a position to make demands to the supervisor and the supervisor is most likely unaware of Devon’s situation; this comment is inflammatory and unnecessary

questions.text: Ask Devon if he needs any help or support
questions.explanation: Devon is evidently under pressure and having a difficult time, as such Leah should reach out to him to see if he needs any assistance

questions.text: Advise Devon to discuss this matter with his academic advisor
questions.explanation: While it is definitely appropriate for Devon to discuss his difficulties with his advisor, this does not address the immediate situation with the supervisor that Devon finds himself in

situations.text: Mason is a junior doctor working in a rural hospital and a patient is rushed in at short notice during Mason’s break. During this break, Mason was expected to meet with his supervisor. However, this patient is in an urgent condition and needs immediate treatment. There are no other doctors available. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Mason?

questions.text: Proceed to the meeting as it is his break, and he has no obligation to see the patient
questions.explanation: This patient urgently needs treatment and there are no other doctors available, this must take priority over Mason’s break and his meeting

questions.text: Ask the nurse to keep the patient stable while he attends the meeting
questions.explanation: While not as bad as simply not seeing the patient, this patient urgently needs treatment and may not be able to be kept stable and, hence, Mason should not attend the meeting

questions.text: Tend to the patient
questions.explanation: This patient urgently needs treatment the other doctors are not available; hence, Mason should see this patient

questions.text: Let the supervisor know you won’t be able to attend the meeting
questions.explanation: Providing that time permits this, Mason should let the supervisor know that he will not be able to attend. If the patient is in an urgent condition, this may not be possible

questions.text: Take a few minutes to calm down and come up with a reasonable course of action
questions.explanation: While it is important to be calm and measured in approach, the patient is in urgent need of care so there likely isn’t time to do this

situations.text: You are a GP. A patient is becoming irate and complains that the medical student, whom you are supervising, is being rude and threatening. This patient is notoriously difficult and, from your experience with them, the medical student is both polite and friendly. How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Dismiss the patient’s concerns
questions.explanation: Patient concerns should never be dismissed – they must be explored further

questions.text: Apologise to the patient for the medical student’s behaviour
questions.explanation: While this may help diffuse the situation, apologising on behalf of the student is inappropriate as you don’t actually know whether the student has done anything wrong

questions.text: Investigate the patient’s concerns further
questions.explanation: Patient concerns should never be dismissed – they must be explored further

questions.text: Tell the patient, politely, to calm down
questions.explanation: This response is counterproductive and will likely only function to anger the patient further

questions.text: Privately ask the medical student for their perspective on the issue
questions.explanation: Before proceeding further, it is important to gather more information and hear both sides of the story
